metadata.name: Simple RO-Crate Dataset
metadata.description: Implements the basic RO-Crate elements found in the specification and common examples. Start here for exploring the tool.
metadata.author: University of Queensland

inputs.name: identifier
inputs.help: The identifier property represents any kind of identifier for any kind of [[Thing]], such as ISBNs, GTIN codes, UUIDs, etc. Schema.org provides dedicated properties for representing many of these, either as textual strings or as URL (URI) links.

inputs.name: about
inputs.help: The subject matter of the content.

inputs.name: citation
inputs.help: A citation or reference to another creative work, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc.

inputs.name: contentLocation
inputs.help: The location depicted or described in the content. For example, the location in a photograph or painting.

inputs.name: author
inputs.help: The author of this content.

inputs.name: datePublished
inputs.help: Date of first broadcast or publication.

inputs.name: pcdm:hasMember
inputs.help: The sub-collections, if any, associated with this collection.

inputs.name: hasPart
inputs.help: Indicates an item or CreativeWork that is part of this item, or CreativeWork (in some sense).

inputs.name: isPartOf
inputs.help: Indicates an item or CreativeWork that this item, or CreativeWork (in some sense), is part of.

inputs.name: pcdm:memberOf
inputs.help: Links from a Repository Object or Collection to a containing Repository Object or Collection.

inputs.name: keywords
inputs.help: Keywords or tags used to describe some item. Multiple textual entries in a keywords list are typically delimited by commas, or by repeating the property.

inputs.name: publisher
inputs.help: The publisher of the creative work.

inputs.name: temporalCoverage
inputs.help: The temporalCoverage of a CreativeWork indicates the period that the content applies to, i.e. that it describes, either as a DateTime or as a textual string indicating a time period in [ISO 8601 time interval format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Time_intervals). In the case of a Dataset it will typically indicate the relevant time period in a precise notation (e.g. for a 2011 census dataset, the year 2011 would be written "2011/2012"). Other forms of content, e.g. ScholarlyArticle, Book, TVSeries or TVEpisode, may indicate their temporalCoverage in broader terms - textually or via well-known URL. Written works such as books may sometimes have precise temporal coverage too, e.g. a work set in 1939 - 1945 can be indicated in ISO 8601 interval format format via "1939/1945". Open-ended date ranges can be written with ".." in place of the end date. For example, "2015-11/.." indicates a range beginning in November 2015 and with no specified final date. This is tentative and might be updated in future when ISO 8601 is officially updated.

inputs.name: encodingFormat
inputs.help: Media type typically expressed using a MIME format (see [IANA site](http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml) and [MDN reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types)), e.g. application/zip for a SoftwareApplication binary, audio/mpeg for .mp3 In cases where a [[CreativeWork]] has several media type representations, [[encoding]] can be used to indicate each [[MediaObject]] alongside particular [[encodingFormat]] information. Unregistered or niche encoding and file formats can be indicated instead via the most appropriate URL, e.g. defining Web page or a Wikipedia/Wikidata entry.

inputs.name: fileFormat
inputs.help: Media type, typically MIME format (see [IANA site](http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml)) of the content, e.g. application/zip of a SoftwareApplication binary. In cases where a CreativeWork has several media type representations, 'encoding' can be used to indicate each MediaObject alongside particular fileFormat information. Unregistered or niche file formats can be indicated instead via the most appropriate URL, e.g. defining Web page or a Wikipedia entry.

inputs.name: version
inputs.help: The version of the CreativeWork embodied by a specified resource.

inputs.name: funder
inputs.help: A person or organization that supports (sponsors) something through some kind of financial contribution.

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: A description of the item.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the item.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the item.

inputs.name: value
inputs.help: The value of the quantitative value or property value node. For [[QuantitativeValue]] and [[MonetaryAmount]], the recommended type for values is 'Number'. For [[PropertyValue]], it can be 'Text', 'Number', 'Boolean', or 'StructuredValue'. Use values from 0123456789 (Unicode 'DIGIT ZERO' (U+0030) to 'DIGIT NINE' (U+0039)) rather than superficially similar Unicode symbols. Use '.' (Unicode 'FULL STOP' (U+002E)) rather than ',' to indicate a decimal point. Avoid using these symbols as a readability separator.

inputs.name: contactType
inputs.help: A person or organization can have different contact points, for different purposes. For example, a sales contact point, a PR contact point and so on. This property is used to specify the kind of contact point.

inputs.name: latitude
inputs.help: The latitude of a location. For example ```37.42242``` ([WGS 84](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Geodetic_System)).

inputs.name: longitude
inputs.help: The longitude of a location. For example ```-122.08585``` ([WGS 84](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Geodetic_System)).

inputs.name: identifier
inputs.help: The identifier property represents any kind of identifier for any kind of [[Thing]], such as ISBNs, GTIN codes, UUIDs, etc. Schema.org provides dedicated properties for representing many of these, either as textual strings or as URL (URI) links.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the item.

inputs.name: contentUrl
inputs.help: Actual bytes of the media object, for example the image file or video file.

inputs.name: endTime
inputs.help: The endTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to end. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. E.g. John wrote a book from January to *December*. For media, including audio and video, it's the time offset of the end of a clip within a larger file. Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.

inputs.name: contentSize
inputs.help: File size in (mega/kilo)bytes.

inputs.name: encodingFormat
inputs.help: Media type typically expressed using a MIME format (see [IANA site](http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml) and [MDN reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types)), e.g. application/zip for a SoftwareApplication binary, audio/mpeg for .mp3. In cases where a [[CreativeWork]] has several media type representations, [[encoding]] can be used to indicate each [[MediaObject]] alongside particular [[encodingFormat]] information. Unregistered or niche encoding and file formats can be indicated instead via the most appropriate URL, e.g. defining Web page or a Wikipedia/Wikidata entry.

inputs.name: description

inputs.name: identifier
inputs.help: The identifier property represents any kind of identifier for any kind of [[Thing]], such as ISBNs, GTIN codes, UUIDs, etc. Schema.org provides dedicated properties for representing many of these, either as textual strings or as URL (URI) links.

inputs.name: manufacturer
inputs.help: The manufacturer of the product.

inputs.name: model
inputs.help: The model of the product. Use with the URL of a ProductModel or a textual representation of the model identifier. The URL of the ProductModel can be from an external source. It is recommended to additionally provide strong product identifiers via the gtin8/gtin13/gtin14 and mpn properties.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the item.

inputs.name: serialNumber
inputs.help: The serial number or any alphanumeric identifier of a particular product. When attached to an offer, it is a shortcut for the serial number of the product included in the offer.

inputs.name: agent
inputs.help: The direct performer or driver of the action (animate or inanimate). E.g. *John* wrote a book.

inputs.name: description
inputs.help: A description of the item.

inputs.name: endTime
inputs.help: The endTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to end. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. E.g. John wrote a book from January to *December*. For media, including audio and video, it's the time offset of the end of a clip within a larger file. Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.

inputs.name: identifier
inputs.help: The identifier property represents any kind of identifier for any kind of [[Thing]], such as ISBNs, GTIN codes, UUIDs, etc. Schema.org provides dedicated properties for representing many of these, either as textual strings or as URL (URI) links.

inputs.name: instrument
inputs.help: The object that helped the agent perform the action. E.g. John wrote a book with *a pen*.

inputs.name: name
inputs.help: The name of the item.

inputs.name: object
inputs.help: The object upon which the action is carried out, whose state is kept intact or changed. Also known as the semantic roles patient, affected or undergoer (which change their state) or theme (which doesn't). E.g. John read *a book*.

inputs.name: result
inputs.help: The result produced in the action. E.g. John wrote *a book*.

inputs.name: URL
inputs.help: Data type: URL.
